cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: When traveling long distances, you should:
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: Most heavy-duty vehicles use ____ air brake systems.
questions.explanation: The majority of heavy-duty vehicles are equipped with dual air brake systems.

questions.question: You may:
questions.answerA: Have more than one license if one is for business purposes.
questions.answerB: Have more than one license if they are issued by different states.
questions.answerC: Not have more than one license.
questions.explanation: A person cannot have more than one driver license at a time. States share information through a computer database to ensure that no person has more than one license. Violation of this law could result in fines or jail time.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer, you should begin by:
questions.answerA: Turning the steering wheel in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Turning the wheel as sharply as possible.
questions.explanation: When backing with a trailer, begin by turning the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the turn. Once the trailer starts to turn, reverse the direction of the steering wheel to follow the trailer.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: When turning, when should the turn signal be canceled?
questions.explanation: Always signal continuously through a turn. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is finished.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerA: Keep cargo in a large box.
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from sliding in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from falling out of a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking may be used on all sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Vehicles with dual air brake systems:
questions.answerA: Maintain full-capacity air pressure in the braking systems even when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerB: Maintain some air pressure in the braking systems when the vehicle is not running.
questions.answerC: Must be run to build enough air pressure to brakes to operate properly.
questions.answerD: Do not need time to build air pressure before a trip.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must allow the air compressor time to build up at least 100 psi of air pressure in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill:
questions.answerD: You will slow to a stop.
questions.explanation: When a vehicle is traveling on a downward slope, the force of gravity will cause its speed to increase.

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, once air pressure is lost and the spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: You will be unable to move the vehicle.
questions.answerB: A separate air tank can be used to release the spring brakes for a short period of time.
questions.answerC: You can use the spring brakes to continue driving normally.
questions.answerD: The air tanks will automatically refill to a safe air pressure level.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerC: Drive straight into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Your horn should be used to:
questions.answerA: Tell other drivers that you are angry.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers that you are near.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's horn is a tool to warn others of your presence. Because the horn may create danger by startling other drivers, you should use it only if necessary.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: Most drivers are the least alert:
questions.explanation: Fatigue and lack of alertness are major hazards when driving at night. Most people are the least alert at night, especially after midnight.

questions.question: When inspecting the exhaust system for defects, which of the following should be fixed?
questions.answerB: A broken exhaust pipe, muffler, or tailpipe
questions.explanation: Exhaust system defects can be extremely serious because they may make it possible for poisonous fumes to enter into the cab or sleeper berth. Issues to check for in a pre-trip inspection include loose, broken, or missing exhaust pipes, mufflers, tailpipes, vertical stacks, mounting brackets, clamps, bolts, or nuts; exhaust system parts that are rubbing against fuel system parts, tires, or other moving parts of the vehicle; and exhaust system parts that are leaking.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerA: Only occurs at extremely high speeds.
questions.answerB: Can occur at speeds as slow as 30 mph.
questions.answerC: Happens most frequently when tire pressure is too high.
questions.answerD: Happens most frequently when tires have good tread.
questions.explanation: If there is enough water on the road, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph. It is most likely if the tires' air pressure is too low or if tires' tread is worn.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: After the engine is started, warning lights and buzzers should all:
questions.answerD: Turn off once the vehicle begins moving.
questions.explanation: After the engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers should deactivate immediately. The charging circuit warning, oil, coolant, and Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) lights should all turn off.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: What are placards?
questions.answerA: Signs placed on a vehicle to identify cargo hazards
questions.answerB: A type of tire used in snowy conditions
questions.explanation: Placards are diamond-shaped warning signs that are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. Placards are used to identify the specific hazard classes of the cargo being carried.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: Brakes may get out of adjustment:
questions.explanation: Brakes can get out of adjustment quickly, especially if they are used to the point of overheating. Brake adjustment should be checked frequently.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain what you would inspect and why.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be required to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. During this inspection, you must explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why you are inspecting those items.

questions.question: Why should the steps of a pre-trip inspection be done in the same order each time?
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget a step.
questions.answerD: The form must be followed in order.
questions.explanation: Doing an inspection the same way every time will help you learn the necessary steps. You will be less likely to forget a step if you get into a routine.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal:
questions.explanation: When stopping, the brake pedal should be pushed down gradually. Control the pressure so your vehicle comes to a slow, safe stop.

questions.question: Why do you need to drain air tanks regularly?
questions.answerA: Because the air gets old and needs to be replaced
questions.answerB: Because compressed air contains some water which must be drained from the tanks
questions.answerC: To allow for a change in air pressure
questions.answerD: To remove bad air from the tanks
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: If one-fourth of the leaves in a leaf spring are missing when a vehicle is inspected:
questions.answerA: The vehicle’s driver will be allowed to drive, but only at reduced speeds.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be put out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will be fine to drive since most of the spring is in place.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle's suspension, you should look for broken or missing leaves in the leaf springs. Any defect of this kind is dangerous. If one-fourth or more of the leaves are missing from any leaf spring, the vehicle must be put out-of-service.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tanks have drains to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. Allowing water and oil to accumulate in the system could cause damage to the brakes.

questions.question: Failing to drain the tanks in an air brake system can result in:
questions.answerA: Water freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do this can cause damage. For example, water that has built up in the system could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the locking jaws are open.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer coupling, you should make sure the fifth wheel locking jaws are closed around the shank of the kingpin, not the head of the kingpin.

questions.question: Scan the road ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Good drivers scan the road at least 12 to 15 seconds ahead of their vehicles. Looking ahead will allow you to identify and react to hazards before meeting them. Be sure to specifically look for vehicles that are coming onto the highway, entering into your lane, or turning.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: When inspecting a power steering-equipped vehicle, you should be sure that:
questions.answerA: The fluid is at the proper level.
questions.answerB: The hoses are connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: The hoses do not contain any fluid.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. Be sure to check for and repair leaks before operating the vehicle.

questions.question: A fatigued driver:
questions.answerB: Should take over-the-counter remedies to wake them up.
questions.answerC: May make critical decisions too slowly.
questions.answerD: Is usually more conscientious than a typical driver.
questions.explanation: If you are fatigued, you will not see or react to hazards as quickly as you would if you were fully energized and awake. You will be impaired in making critical decisions.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping on the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brakes are controlled by a diamond-shaped yellow knob. Pull the knob out to activate the parking brakes and push it in to release them.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.explanation: The force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling downhill.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerC: Is usually aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerD: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Driving while distracted may result in slowed perception, delayed decision-making, and improper actions. Watch for distracted drivers and avoid them, when possible.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: Allow the rear wheels to lock up
questions.answerB: Allow all wheels to lock up
questions.answerD: Alert other motorists when you are braking
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be fuel spilled on the ground that could catch fire.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares if the weather is sunny.
questions.explanation: A common cause of vehicle fires in the aftermath of an accident is the improper use of flares near spilled fuel. Use flares with caution.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: If you’re not sure what to do to extinguish a fire in your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire in your vehicle, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerA: You are unlikely to be caught.
questions.answerD: There is no way for authorities to find out.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer:
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the incident. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency within 30 days if the incident happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-drive inspection:
questions.answerA: The inspection report is not important.
questions.answerB: The inspection report must only be reviewed if there will be passengers in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: The previous inspection report should be reviewed, if applicable.
questions.explanation: The first step of a vehicle inspection is to review the last vehicle inspection report. Only sign the report if noted defects are certified to have been repaired.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: While testing for a CDL, an applicant will be required to go through a full vehicle inspection. The vehicle inspection test will include an engine oil level check.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerA: But only if it is cold outside.
questions.answerC: Both when it is cold and hot outside.
questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: Hanging meat in a refrigerated truck:
questions.answerA: Is a good way for inexperienced drivers to gain experience.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: When conducting a vehicle inspection, you must show each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: That the oil pressure gauge is working.
questions.answerB: That the oil pressure warning light turns off, or that the gauge shows increasing or normal oil pressure.
questions.answerC: That the oil temperature gauge, if equipped, rises to the normal operating range.
questions.answerD: That the oil pressure gauge comes on when brakes are used.
questions.explanation: When checking the oil pressure gauge as part of a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that it is working. The gauge should show increasing or normal oil pressure, or the oil pressure warning light should turn off. If equipped with one, the oil temperature gauge should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: When it is difficult for others to see your vehicle, such as at dawn or dusk, you can help other drivers by:
questions.answerD: Waving an arm out the window.
questions.explanation: At times when visibility is low, you should turn your headlights on to the low beam setting. If you are having a difficult time seeing others, they are probably having a difficult time seeing you.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: What are placards?
questions.answerA: Signs placed on a vehicle to identify cargo hazards
questions.answerB: A type of tire used in snowy conditions
questions.explanation: Placards are diamond-shaped warning signs that are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. Placards are used to identify the specific hazard classes of the cargo being carried.

questions.question: The height of a vehicle’s center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Usually has no impact on the handling the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Plays a large role in a driver's ability to safely handle the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Should not be a concern when loading the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Should only be a concern if there are lots of hills on the planned route.
questions.explanation: The height of a vehicle's center of gravity is very important to a driver's ability to safely handle the vehicle. Always distribute the weight of cargo as low as possible.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.explanation: The force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase when traveling downhill.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, warning lights and buzzers:
questions.answerA: Should stay on for several minutes.
questions.answerB: Should turn off within a few seconds.
questions.answerC: Should stay on until manually turned off.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers for oil, coolant, charging circuits, and the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) should go out right away.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, the most important thing for you to do is get out of their way. Avoid making eye contact, do not challenge them by increasing your speed, and do not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they direct toward you.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: When near a railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: You should expect to hear every approaching train.
questions.answerB: You may not hear a train, even if one is approaching.
questions.answerC: You will hear two short blasts of a train's horn if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: You should never assume that you will hear an approaching train. The train operator may fail to sound the horn, or the use of a train's horn may be prohibited in a specific area. Even if the train does sound its horn, noise from inside your own vehicle may prevent you from hearing the train until it is dangerously close.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: The brake pedal is part of which braking system?
questions.explanation: The service brake system applies and releases the brakes when a driver presses the brake pedal while driving normally.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: Cargo being transported should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and again within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. Cargo should be inspected every time the driver stops to take a break. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: When encountering a railroad crossing during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is moving too slowly.
questions.answerB: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash down the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull over and yell at them.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the other driver’s behavior to police.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: You are especially likely to encounter strong winds when:
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult to keep a vehicle in its proper lane. Strong wind can be a particular problem when a vehicle is being driven out of a tunnel.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: If mirrors are dirty before starting a trip:
questions.answerA: They will likely become clean after driving a short distance.
questions.answerB: It should not be a concern.
questions.answerC: They should be cleaned before the vehicle is driven.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, be sure to check the mirrors and windshield for dirt and anything else that could interfere with your ability to see. Clean them as necessary.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Usually are not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care when being driven because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should also be careful because the materials being carried can easily shift in transit, causing a change in the vehicle's handling.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If equipped, a header board should:
questions.answerC: Be strong enough to contain cargo.
questions.answerD: Light up when the engine is started.
questions.explanation: When checking a header board during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that it is secure, free of damage, and strong enough to contain cargo.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks have an air pressure level of:
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, it should be secured by at least ____ tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and tell them of the driver's behavior.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal:
questions.explanation: When stopping, the brake pedal should be pushed down gradually. Control the pressure so your vehicle comes to a slow, safe stop.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: To warn drivers behind you that you will be slowing down, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn on the right turn signal followed by the left turn signal.
questions.answerB: Tap your brake pedal a few times to illuminate your brake lights.
questions.answerC: Swerve from side to side to get their attention.
questions.explanation: To let drivers behind you know that you plan to slow down, lightly tap your brake pedal a few times to flash your brake lights. It is important to communicate your intentions to other drivers.

questions.question: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share:
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake system share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Front wheel braking works:
questions.answerC: Only if the road is dry.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: During the pre-trip vehicle inspection test:
questions.answerA: Applicants will not have to identify the ABS.
questions.answerB: Windshield wipers are not to be addressed.
questions.answerC: Shock absorbers only need to be checked on one axle.
questions.answerD: The steering box should be checked for leaks.
questions.explanation: During the external inspection portion of the pre-trip vehicle inspection test, you must verify that the steering box is securely mounted and not leaking.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Usually are not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care when being driven because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should also be careful because the materials being carried can easily shift in transit, causing a change in the vehicle's handling.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard:
questions.answerA: You should always steer to the left.
questions.answerB: You may be able to drive onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: You should steer sharply in one direction.
questions.explanation: In some emergencies, the best strategy for avoiding a hazard may be to drive onto the shoulder. Most shoulders are strong enough to support the weight of a large vehicle.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.explanation: Steering wheel play of more than 10 degrees (about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch steering wheel) can make it difficult to steer.

questions.question: During the driving test, when encountering a railroad crossing, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass another vehicle on the tracks if the other vehicle is going too slow.
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle to check for a train.
questions.answerC: Not change gears while your vehicle is on the tracks.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, do not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in a railroad crossing.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: When transporting a load, the cargo should be inspected:
questions.answerA: Only at the beginning of a drive.
questions.answerB: Only after driving a long distance.
questions.explanation: Cargo and its securing devices must be inspected before starting a trip. After beginning a trip, the driver should check the load and securing devices within the first 50 miles on the road, every three hours or 150 miles traveled, and after every break.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the ____ come on automatically when air pressure falls below 45 psi.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure levels drop to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: You should always use at least ____ to secure cargo on a flatbed trailer.
questions.explanation: When transporting cargo on a flatbed trailer, you should use at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Any cargo, no matter how small, should be restrained by a minimum of two tie-downs.

questions.question: The only way to sober up after consuming alcohol is to:
questions.explanation: Most alcohol is removed from the body by the liver, which processes alcohol at a fixed rate. Despite popular belief, techniques like drinking black coffee or taking a cold shower will not accelerate this process. The only thing you can do to become sober after drinking is allow your body the time it needs to eliminate the alcohol from your system.

questions.question: If a truck's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at slow speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.answerD: The truck will lack brakes on its left side.
questions.explanation: If an ABS system fails, the vehicle will still have normal braking function. The driver should continue to drive and brake as they normally would.

questions.question: When checking your tires, which of the following is not an issue to correct?
questions.answerC: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerD: Tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch on the front tires
questions.explanation: Problems to check for when inspecting tires include: air pressure that is too low or too high; using radial and bias-ply tires together; tread depth of less than 4/32 of an inch in major grooves on front tires; and tread depth of less than 2/32 of an inch on all other tires.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: Service brakes should:
questions.answerB: Only be tested by a trained mechanic.
questions.explanation: Before driving, you should always verify that your service brakes are in good working order. Testing the brakes before a trip allows you to locate any problems before you need to brake while on the road.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a traffic violation:
questions.answerA: The State will inform your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.answerC: Number of meals eaten by the driver
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the origin and destination points of the trip and the Vehicle Identification Number.

questions.question: What is traction?
questions.answerA: Friction between the tires and road
questions.answerC: The length of time needed to activate the brakes
questions.explanation: Traction is friction between your tires and the surface of the road. Adequate traction is necessary for braking and steering.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: An air compressor governor controls:
questions.answerA: When the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerB: How fast air is pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: The temperature of the air pumped into the air storage tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor governor controls when the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks.

questions.question: A commercial motor vehicle driver:
questions.answerA: May use any cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: May only use a hands-free cell phone while driving, if permitted.
questions.answerC: May only use a cell phone while driving on rural roads.
questions.explanation: If you choose to use a mobile phone while operating a CMV, you may only use a hands-free mobile phone that is located close to you. However, even a hands-free mobile phone can be a dangerous distraction while driving. Make sure you are aware of all cell phone laws in the state in which you are driving.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: An item that is 40 feet long placed on a flatbed trailer should be secured by at least ____ tie-down(s).
questions.explanation: Cargo on a flatbed trailer should be secured by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of the cargo's length. Cargo should be secured by a minimum of two tie-downs, regardless of size.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good way to reduce crashes when turning right?
questions.answerB: Keep the tail end close to the curb.
questions.answerC: Keep an eye on oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Allow open space on your right side.
questions.explanation: When making a right turn, avoid turning too wide to the left. If you must swing into another lane to complete the turn, you should keep the rear of your vehicle close to the curb. Leaving space to the right of your vehicle while turning right may indicate to other drivers that you are turning left, so they may attempt to pass you on your right.

questions.question: When driving through fog, a driver should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: When driving under wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that:
questions.answerA: Ice has formed on the road.
questions.answerC: The spray is caught on the underside of the vehicle.
questions.explanation: In wet conditions, a lack of spray coming from the tires of other vehicles indicates that ice has formed on the road. Be especially cautious when traveling under wet conditions in freezing weather.

questions.question: Which of the following is not another name for convex mirrors?
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are also known as "fisheye", "spot", or "bug-eye" mirrors.

questions.question: What may happen if the exhaust system is not working properly?
questions.answerA: Poisonous fumes may enter the cab.
questions.answerB: Poisonous fumes may exit the rear of the muffler system.
questions.answerD: It may cause problems if the trailer is fully loaded.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can allow poisonous fumes to enter a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to regularly check your exhaust system for defects.

questions.question: What color light indicates a vehicle's ABS is not working?
questions.explanation: On vehicles with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS), yellow malfunction lamps alert the driver to ABS malfunction.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a cab due to:
questions.answerB: Using the wrong type of fuel.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: A faulty exhaust system is a serious safety hazard. It may allow poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: What is a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating?
questions.answerA: The maximum weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a single vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a single vehicle
questions.answerD: The maximum amount that can be loaded onto a single trailer
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the weight specified by the manufacturer as the maximum weight of a single vehicle and its load.

questions.question: The suspension system:
questions.answerA: Holds up the vehicle and its load.
questions.answerB: Keeps the load the proper distance behind the driver’s compartment.
questions.answerC: Maintains a safe distance between the vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerD: Lightens the load for the tires.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Damage to a suspension system can be very dangerous.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: Sometimes, when checking the automatic transmission fluid level:
questions.answerA: Your vehicle should be parked uphill.
questions.answerB: Your vehicle should be parked downhill.
questions.answerD: Your vehicle may have to be left running.
questions.explanation: In some vehicles, you may have to leave the engine running to check the automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: When starting the vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, the coolant temperature should:
questions.explanation: After starting your vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, you should watch the gauges. The coolant temperature should gradually rise to a normal operating range.

questions.question: A danger of swerving to avoid a hazard while driving a large truck is that:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.explanation: While swerving can sometimes be the safest way to handle a hazard on the roadway, doing so is not without risk. Top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over in a swerve.

questions.question: The most common type of foundation brake used is the:
questions.explanation: The most common type of foundation brake is an s-cam drum brake.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: How much water is needed on a road surface for a vehicle to hydroplane?
questions.answerB: A good amount, such as a large puddle
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be much water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: An open automobile window in cold weather may indicate that the driver is:
questions.answerC: Using the heat inside their vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' behaviors and identify clues that indicate when person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. A person driving with their window open in cold weather may be impaired.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: What is axle weight?
questions.answerA: The weight transmitted to the ground by one axle
questions.answerC: How much weight an axle can hold
questions.explanation: "Axle weight" refers to the weight transmitted to the ground by one axle or one set of axles.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you would inspect and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load in a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the CDL vehicle inspection test, you must be able to inspect your vehicle and explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Factors that can affect your vehicle's stopping distance include driving speed, the vehicle's weight, and the slipperiness of the road surface.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A double combination vehicle should have a leakage rate no higher than 4 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern.
questions.answerB: Is not a concern if passengers are not unloading.
questions.answerC: Should not be on the roadway.
questions.answerD: Is a concern, whether passengers are visible or not.
questions.explanation: Always drive cautiously around a stopped bus. Passengers may cross in front of or behind it, and the bus may prevent them from seeing your vehicle.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of a pre-trip inspection, seeing fresh oil underneath the vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle, you should check under the vehicle for fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks. Spotting any of these before a trip is a cause for concern.

questions.question: A danger of swerving to avoid a hazard while driving a large truck is that:
questions.answerA: The truck may miss the object.
questions.answerC: The truck may stay in the same lane.
questions.explanation: While swerving can sometimes be the safest way to handle a hazard on the roadway, doing so is not without risk. Top-heavy vehicles and tractors with multiple trailers may flip over in a swerve.

questions.question: Headlights:
questions.answerA: Are not usually necessary when driving at night.
questions.answerB: Provide better light than the sun.
questions.answerC: Should be on the high beam setting whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Should always be on the high beam setting.
questions.explanation: To improve visibility, you should use high beam headlights at night where it is safe and legal to do so. However, the glare from high beam lights can blind other drivers. You should dim your lights to their low beam setting when driving within 500 feet of an approaching vehicle.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: If a driver has stopped on the road and is placing triangles to warn other motorists:
questions.answerA: The triangles should be held between the driver and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The triangles should be carried behind the driver's back to prevent them from being seen by other drivers until they are placed.
questions.answerC: The triangles should be held as low as possible.
questions.explanation: For your own safety, when placing reflective warning triangles, you should carry them between your body and the oncoming traffic.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located ____ a brake drum.
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Exit the road and park as soon as safely possible.
questions.answerC: Stop where you are and park.
questions.answerD: Put on your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of hydraulic brake failure?
questions.explanation: Most cases of hydraulic brake failure come from one of two causes. The brakes may fail due to a loss of hydraulic pressure or due to overuse on long hills, causing the brakes to fade.

questions.question: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Check traffic thoroughly in all directions.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Keep your vehicle in its lane.
questions.answerD: Steadily use the brakes throughout the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving test, you should thoroughly check traffic in all directions. Before entering the curve, reduce your speed sufficiently so that further braking or shifting is not required. Keep your vehicle in its lane and continue checking traffic in all directions.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerB: The trailer disengages from the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle becomes easier to control.
questions.explanation: On a wet road, it is possible for a vehicle's tires to lose traction with the road surface and begin to glide along on the layer of water. This is referred to as hydroplaning. Hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: If a traffic light has been green for a long time:
questions.answerA: It will probably stay green as you approach.
questions.answerC: It is likely that the light will soon change to yellow.
questions.answerD: It is likely the light will skip yellow and change from green to red.
questions.explanation: If you are approaching a traffic light that has been green for a long time, there is a good chance that it will turn yellow before you reach it. Start slowing down and be ready to stop.

questions.question: Bridges usually:
questions.answerA: Freeze, but only once the temperature drops significantly below 32 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.answerB: Freeze after other road surfaces freeze.
questions.answerD: Have heaters to prevent them from freezing.
questions.explanation: Bridges usually freeze before the rest of the road. You should be especially careful when crossing bridges if the temperature is near the freezing point.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: When using mirrors while driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Look in the mirrors for extended periods of time.
questions.answerD: Use only the driver’s side mirror.
questions.explanation: Focusing on your mirrors for too long can be dangerous because you will have traveled a substantial distance without looking at the road ahead.

questions.question: The front of an enclosed trailer should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting an enclosed trailer as a part of the vehicle inspection test, check the front area of the trailer for signs of damage, such as cracks, bulges, or holes.

questions.question: In hot weather, spots on the pavement where tar is bleeding:
questions.answerB: Offer the same amount of traction as the rest of the roadway.
questions.answerC: Offer more traction than the rest of the roadway.
questions.explanation: Tar in road pavement often rises to the surface of the road, or "bleeds," in very hot weather. Watch for such areas because they can be very slippery.

questions.question: When starting from a complete stop, a vehicle should:
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting vehicles behind you, you must ensure that your vehicle will not roll backward when you start moving forward from a stopped position.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: Which of the following may result in an applicant being denied a hazardous materials endorsement?
questions.answerA: They are not a lawful permanent resident of the United States.
questions.answerB: They have had a speeding conviction within the previous three years.
questions.answerC: They did not correctly answer every question on the written hazardous materials endorsement test.
questions.answerD: They did not pass the written hazardous materials endorsement test on the first attempt.
questions.explanation: You will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement, or lose an existing endorsement, if you renounce your U.S. citizenship; are not a lawful permanent U.S. resident; are wanted for, indicted for, or convicted of certain felonies; are judged mentally defective or are committed to a mental institution; or are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to pose a security threat.

questions.question: If a truck is equipped, a trailer brake hand valve can be used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent the truck from rolling back when being started from a stop.
questions.explanation: If a tractor-trailer is so equipped, the trailer brake hand valve can be used to stop the vehicle from rolling back when being started from a stop.

questions.question: If your wheels being to spin when accelerating on a poor traction surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the accelerator.
questions.explanation: If your drive wheels begin to spin while accelerating on a surface with poor traction, you should remove your foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: What is a Gross Vehicle Weight Rating?
questions.answerA: The maximum weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a single vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a single vehicle
questions.answerD: The maximum amount that can be loaded onto a single trailer
questions.explanation: Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the weight specified by the manufacturer as the maximum weight of a single vehicle and its load.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in the air brake system releases air:
questions.answerB: The air pressure has become too high.
questions.explanation: An air brake system has a safety relief valve, which releases air from the tanks if the pressure gets too high. If the valve must operate, something in the system is wrong and should be addressed by a mechanic.

questions.question: Sending text messages while driving:
questions.answerA: May be done if the messages are short.
questions.answerC: Is permitted if you are asking a question of your employer.
questions.explanation: Sending and reading text messages while driving is prohibited.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections are:
questions.answerB: Needed only for trips longer than 100 miles in length.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before every trip, regardless of length.

questions.question: If something is found to be unsafe during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue with the trip and make an appointment with a mechanic after the trip is completed.
questions.answerB: Let a more experienced driver use the truck.
questions.answerD: Not use the items found to be unsafe, but may continue driving normally.
questions.explanation: If a pre-trip inspection reveals anything unsafe about your vehicle, you must get it repaired. It is illegal to operate an unsafe vehicle.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: When driving, you should stop and take a break ____ to avoid becoming too tired.
questions.explanation: To reduce the chances of becoming fatigued on a long trip, a driver should stop for a break at least once every two hours or 100 miles driven.

questions.question: Spring brakes come on:
questions.answerA: When too much air pressure is lost.
questions.answerB: When a control on the dashboard is activated.
questions.answerC: When the tires have minimal tread depth.
questions.explanation: Spring brakes come on automatically when air pressure drops to an unsafe psi level. Instead of waiting for the spring brakes to automatically activate, you should safely exit the road as soon as you notice the low pressure warning signal and bring your vehicle to a stop while you are still able to control the brakes.

questions.question: If you must leave the roadway and drive on the shoulder in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerB: Get both sets of wheels onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has stopped, if possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive onto the shoulder to avoid a hazard, stay on it until you come to a stop; then signal, check your mirrors, and merge back into traffic. Avoid braking on the shoulder at speeds higher than about 20 mph. To help maintain control, always keep one set of wheels on the pavement, if possible.

questions.question: When traveling down a downgrade, the speed of a vehicle will likely:
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the force of gravity will cause a vehicle's speed to increase. When approaching a downgrade, choose to travel at a speed that will be safe for the size and weight of your vehicle.

questions.question: A pre-trip vehicle inspection:
questions.answerA: Is not required if the driver regularly uses the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Is not required for trips under 100 miles.
questions.answerC: Is only to be performed by a mechanic.
questions.explanation: Drivers are required by state and federal law to inspect their vehicles before beginning to drive.

questions.question: When driving at night, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Make sure your glasses are clean.
questions.explanation: To ensure that you can see as well as possible, don't wear sunglasses when driving at night. If you wear eyeglasses, make sure they are clean and unscratched. Make sure you are rested and alert before driving at night.

questions.question: When turning, when should the turn signal be canceled?
questions.explanation: Always signal continuously through a turn. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is finished.

questions.question: Antifreeze helps to keep an engine functioning properly:
questions.answerA: But only if it is cold outside.
questions.answerC: Both when it is cold and hot outside.
