questions.explanation: It is always important to have enough water and antifreeze in a vehicle's cooling system. Despite the name, antifreeze is beneficial to an engine even in hot weather.

questions.question: If federal inspectors judge your vehicle to be unsafe, they can:
questions.answerA: Bring you to a garage to have your vehicle fixed.
questions.answerB: Formerly request that you have your vehicle's problems fixed.
questions.answerD: Pull the vehicle out-of-service until it is fixed.
questions.explanation: If a federal or state inspector judges a CMV to be unsafe, they may put it out-of-service until it is fixed.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: If students on the bus cause a disturbance while other students are unloading, what should you do?
questions.answerA: Immediately walk to the back of the bus and take care of the disturbance while students unload.
questions.answerB: Wait until the students are done unloading and then take care of the disturbance.
questions.answerC: Have a student who is closer to the disturbance handle the situation while you supervise unloading.
questions.explanation: The process of loading or unloading students from a school bus requires a driver's full concentration. If there is a behavioral issue on the bus, wait until the exiting students are safely off the bus and out of the way before you address the problem on the bus.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, be sure that:
questions.answerA: The emergency exits are difficult to open.
questions.answerB: The emergency exit warning devices work properly.
questions.answerD: The emergency exits are not accessible from inside the cab.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that any emergency exit warning devices are working. All emergency exits should operate smoothly, be undamaged, and close securely from the inside.

questions.question: When students are being picked up by a school bus:
questions.answerA: The students should wait at a designated bus stop.
questions.answerB: The driver should stop to pick up students who are walking to a designated bus stop.
questions.answerC: The parents may choose where the bus stops are located.
questions.explanation: School bus drivers may only pick up students at official stops designated by authorized school officials.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: When taking the on-road test, you will be evaluated on regular traffic checks. You should not:
questions.answerC: Avoid checking your mirrors near intersections.
questions.explanation: While taking the on-road driving skills test, check for traffic and use your mirrors regularly, especially when encountering intersections. Scan and check for pedestrians in areas where they may be present.

questions.question: After students unload at the school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with the students' whereabouts.
questions.answerB: Leave after the students have entered the school building.
questions.answerC: Walk through the bus to check for any sleeping students.
questions.explanation: After students unload at school, a school bus driver should walk through the bus to check for sleeping students, hiding students, and items that students may have left behind. Students should exit the bus in an orderly fashion with the driver supervising.

questions.question: When should a bus start moving after students have boarded?
questions.answerA: As soon as the students are through the door
questions.answerB: When the students are near their seats but are still standing
questions.answerC: When the students are seated and looking forward
questions.answerD: As soon as the students cross the standee line
questions.explanation: Once students have boarded a school bus, the driver should wait to move the bus until all of the passengers are seated and looking forward.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.

questions.question: Failing to exit your vehicle properly during an exercise in the basic vehicle control skills test will result in:
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.answerD: An extra point against your score.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: If a driver cannot account for a student after the student has exited the bus, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure and leave the bus to look for the student.
questions.answerB: Assume the student has safely exited the bus.
questions.answerC: Walk to the back of the bus to see if the student got back on.
questions.answerD: Ask another student if they've seen the student.
questions.explanation: During unloading, if a school bus driver cannot account for a student outside of the bus, they should secure the bus and check for the missing student around and underneath the bus.

questions.question: A passive railroad crossing:
questions.answerB: Does not have any control devices.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that do not display any traffic control devices are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a backing maneuver that you will be asked to perform during the basic control skills test?
questions.explanation: Backing maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right, offset back/left, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: The overhead inside mirror should be adjusted to see:
questions.answerA: Outside of the driver’s side of the bus.
questions.answerB: All of the students on the bus.
questions.answerC: Students in the first four rows of the bus.
questions.explanation: The top portion of the overhead inside rearview mirror should be positioned to display the top of the bus's rear window. This mirror positioning should allow the driver to see all of the students on the bus, including the heads of the students sitting immediately behind the driver.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. You should not:
questions.answerB: Select a gear that does not rev the engine.
questions.answerC: Forget to shift through an intersection.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. Select a gear that does not rev or lug the engine; avoid grinding and clashing gears; and avoid shifting through turns or intersections.

questions.question: During the straight line backing exercise, how many times are you permitted to exit the vehicle to check its position?
questions.explanation: During the straight line backing exercise, you are permitted to exit your vehicle to check its position no more than one time.

questions.question: When driving through a curve during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer from your lane if needed to complete the curve.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed after entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Refrain from looking for other vehicles while turning.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving skills test, you must reduce your speed sufficiently before entering the curve so that you do not need to further brake or shift in the curve. Keep the vehicle in its lane and continue to check for traffic in all directions.

questions.question: When performing the stop/start maneuver as a part of the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Cut off other vehicles if needed to get onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Slam on the brakes to stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be asked to pull your vehicle over to the side of the road and stop as if you were going to get out and check something on your vehicle. As you prepare to make this stop, you must check traffic; activate your turn signal; decelerate smoothly with even braking, changing gears as needed; and bring your vehicle to a full stop without coasting.

questions.question: If a student drops an item near a stopped bus, they should:
questions.answerA: Hurry and pick up the item.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.answerD: Have another student pick it up.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous for students to retrieve dropped items because doing so could cause them to disappear from the driver's view at a crucial moment. If an item is dropped, the student should get out of the bus's danger zones, get the attention of the driver, and ask the driver to retrieve the item.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without a moving violation.
questions.answerD: Obey all traffic signs and signals, but only if other traffic is present.
questions.explanation: You must drive in a safe and responsible manner during the on-road driving test. This includes wearing your safety belt; obeying all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and completing the test without an accident or moving violation.

questions.question: What should be used to check for proper tire inflation?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must use a tire gauge to check for proper tire inflation. You will not receive passing credit if you simply kick the tires.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving test, you must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Complete the test without an accident.
questions.answerD: Demonstrate that you can use your cell phone while driving.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must drive in a safe and responsible manner; wear your safety belt; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and complete the test without any accidents or moving violations.

questions.question: If there is a fire on a school bus, the students:
questions.answerB: Should stay on the bus but be moved to a part of the bus unaffected by the fire.
questions.explanation: If a school bus is on fire, or if there is a threat of fire, it is mandatory for a bus driver to evacuate the students from the bus.

questions.question: If you must drive during periods of high winds, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: A school bus's long sides are vulnerable to being pushed by winds. If you must drive in windy conditions, you should maintain a strong grip on the steering wheel, try to anticipate wind gusts, and slow down. If necessary, contact your dispatcher for instructions on how to proceed.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: After driving over a bridge during the driving skills test, you may be asked to recall.
questions.answerB: The color of a sign you just passed.
questions.answerC: How many lanes of traffic there were on the bridge.
questions.answerD: If there was a crosswalk on the bridge.
questions.explanation: If you drive over a bridge during the on-road driving skills test, the examiner may ask you afterwards to recall the bridge's posted weight limit.

questions.question: Properly adjusted mirrors on a school bus allow the driver to see ____ behind the bus.
questions.explanation: Proper mirror adjustment is vital to the safe operation of a school bus. A bus's flat mirrors should be adjusted so the driver is able to see 200 feet, or four bus lengths, behind the bus.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
questions.explanation: When crossing railroad tracks during the on-road driving skills test, you must not stop, change gears, pass another vehicle, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is in the railroad crossing.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that lug nuts are all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: During a vehicle inspection test, you must ensure that all lug nuts are present, free of cracks and distortions, and showing no signs of looseness, such as rust trails or shiny threads. Verify that all bolt holes are free of cracks and distortions.

questions.question: Your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: Exactly where the examiner has instructed it to be.
questions.answerB: Within five feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerD: Within two feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: An encroachment is when:
questions.answerA: A driver does not appear for their scheduled basic skills test.
questions.answerB: A vehicle touches an exercise boundary line during the basic skills test.
questions.answerC: A driver fails one section of the basic skills test.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: When performing the stop/start maneuver as a part of the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Cut off other vehicles if needed to get onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Slam on the brakes to stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be asked to pull your vehicle over to the side of the road and stop as if you were going to get out and check something on your vehicle. As you prepare to make this stop, you must check traffic; activate your turn signal; decelerate smoothly with even braking, changing gears as needed; and bring your vehicle to a full stop without coasting.

questions.question: Before evacuating a bus in response to a hazard, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Ask the students if they want to leave.
questions.answerB: Explain the hazard to the dispatcher and make a decision on how to respond.
questions.answerD: Have students open all the windows.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be the safest and the easiest to supervise if they are not evacuated from the school bus. If there is time, the driver should contact their dispatcher to explain the emergency situation before making the decision to evacuate.

questions.question: If you come to railroad tracks while driving a school bus, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Check the tracks, but continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerB: Stop 15 to 50 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerC: Stop 75 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.explanation: In general, school bus drivers should stop before any railroad crossings to check the tracks for approaching trains. Drivers should stop no closer than 15 feet and no farther than 50 feet from the nearest rail in order to have the best view of the tracks. They should look and listen for approaching trains before proceeding through the crossing.

questions.question: When asked to make a turn while taking your driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your turn signal, but only if other cars are present.
questions.answerB: Check traffic only in the direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a turn during the on-road driving test, you must check traffic in all directions and use your turn signal.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: When asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pass the parking space while backing, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.answerD: Back into the parking space without passing it first.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Once stopped as part of the stop/start maneuver, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep the vehicle in first gear.
questions.explanation: When parking as a part of the stop/start maneuver during the on-road driving skills test, you must apply the parking brake. The gears should be shifted into neutral or park. You must be parked parallel to the curb and should not be blocking any driveways or intersections.

questions.question: To distinguish between hazardous and non-hazardous materials on a shipping paper:
questions.answerA: The hazardous materials should be listed at the bottom of the paper.
questions.answerB: The hazardous materials should be listed at the top of the paper.
questions.answerC: The hazardous materials should be highlighted in the same color as the non-hazardous materials.
questions.answerD: The non-hazardous materials should be marked with an "X."
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be differentiated in one of three ways. They must be listed first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description in a column labeled "HM."

questions.question: Containers of nitric acid should be:
questions.answerA: Stacked no more than two containers high.
questions.answerC: Loaded on top of other products.
questions.explanation: Nitric acid should not be stacked above any other product. Containers of nitric acid may be stacked, but no higher than two containers high.

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you must park at least ____ from any building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, do not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building; a place where people gather; or an open fire.

questions.question: Shippers must keep a copy of shipping papers for:
questions.explanation: Shippers must retain a physical copy or an electronic image of hazardous materials shipping papers for a minimum of two years after the materials are accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the marking and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.answerD: The shipping paper is not in the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to compare a shipping paper to the applicable package markings and labels. Ensure that the shipper has included the correct basic description on the shipping paper and that it matches markings and labels.

questions.question: On a shipping paper describing both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may be identified by being:
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper includes information about both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous items must be clearly identified on the paper. They may be entered first, highlighted in a contrasting color, or identified with an "X" placed before the shipping description.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in a certain type of business, such as a fireworks dealer or pest control firm.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The shipper's business is located in a bad part of town.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical supply businesses, or pest control firms.

questions.question: The National Response Center must be notified of an incident resulting in any of the following, except:
questions.explanation: The National Response Center must be notified of any incident that results in death; hospitalization; $50,000 or more in estimated property damage; an evacuation of the general public or closure of a major transportation route/facility for more then one hour; fire, breakage, spillage, or suspected contamination involving radiation, bacteria, or toxins. Additionally, if the carrier judges the situation to be so serious that it should be reported, it should be reported.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo catches on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put out the fire with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Continue driving to the fire department.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires specialized training and equipment. Unless you possess these yourself, it is best to let emergency personnel deal with the fire.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Shipping papers should be:
questions.answerC: Easily seen by anyone entering the cab.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: The identification number associated with a hazardous material should appear:
questions.answerD: On a bumper sticker on the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It must also appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: While driving, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: While hazardous materials are being transported, shipping papers should either be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be clearly visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest possible route.
questions.explanation: If transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must follow a written route plan. Whenever placarded, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys. Be sure to research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: Placarded vehicles must carry fire extinguishers with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: If a product requires a "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard, the placard must be used when transporting:
questions.answerA: More than 100 pounds of the product.
questions.answerB: More than 50 pounds of the product.
questions.answerD: The product in a leaking container.
questions.explanation: For applicable materials, the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" placard and the appropriate hazard class placard must always be displayed, even for small amounts of the materials.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: If there is a collision involving a vehicle transporting Class 1 explosives, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Not warn others of the danger.
questions.answerC: Keep the explosives inside the vehicle until after separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.answerD: Remove the explosives from the vehicle before separating the vehicles involved in the collision.
questions.explanation: If you are driving a vehicle that is transporting Class 1 explosives and it is involved in an accident, you should warn others of the danger, keep bystanders away, and not allow smoking or open fires near the vehicle. Before separating the vehicles involved in the collision, remove all explosives and place them at least 200 feet away from the vehicles and any occupied buildings.

questions.question: A driver must take the HazMat knowledge test:
questions.explanation: You must take and pass the written English version of the HazMat knowledge test and be cleared through a federal background check before every renewal of your CDL.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: Shippers must keep a copy of shipping papers for:
questions.explanation: Shippers must retain a physical copy or an electronic image of hazardous materials shipping papers for a minimum of two years after the materials are accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: In the Hazardous Materials Table, Column 2 lists:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, the vehicle should not be:
questions.answerA: Parked within 300 feet of a bridge.
questions.answerB: Parked within 40 feet of the road.
questions.answerC: Parked for only short periods of time.
questions.explanation: Except when parking briefly to perform necessary functions for vehicle operation (such as refueling), never park a vehicle carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building. Never park such a vehicle within five feet of the traveled portion of a road. Such vehicles should be parked only briefly.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: A person should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded tank that is used to transport Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases) materials. Additionally, no person should smoke or carry a lit cigar, cigarette, or pipe within 25 feet of any vehicle containing Class 1 (explosives), Class 4 (flammable solids), or Class 4.2 (spontaneously combustible).

questions.question: To know which placard to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard class of the materials.
questions.answerB: The type of container that is holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which placards need to be used, you must know the hazard class of the materials being shipped, the amount of hazardous materials being shipped, and the total weight of all hazardous materials in your vehicle.

questions.question: When transporting Division 1.1 materials, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: Use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors should be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: To operate a vehicle that is used to transport hazardous materials, a driver must have:
questions.answerB: A CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a passenger endorsement.
questions.answerD: A CDL with an air brake endorsement.
questions.explanation: You must have a commercial driver license with a hazardous materials endorsement before driving a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, even if the vehicle is not transporting hazardous materials at the time of operation.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: When you are seated behind the steering wheel, shipping papers should be:
questions.answerD: Taped to the passenger's side window.
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, shipping papers should be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door, or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be easily visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: In general, before loading or unloading any flammable liquids, an engine should be:
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: When loading hazardous materials, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Load the materials away from heat.
questions.explanation: When loading hazardous materials, do not use hooks or tools that could damage containers or other packaging.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: Shipping papers for hazardous materials should always be easily accessible. When a driver is not in their vehicle, hazardous materials' shipping papers should be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If corrosive materials leak in a trailer, the trailer should be:
questions.answerC: Left to air dry without washing.
questions.explanation: Parts of a vehicle that have been exposed to corrosive liquids must be thoroughly washed with water.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: You should not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport materials that are categorized as Class 3 (flammable liquids) or Division 2.1 (gases). Do not smoke or carry a lit cigar, pipe, or cigarette near a vehicle containing flammable or explosive materials.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: If you are transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you may notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.answerD: By keeping the driver's side door open.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road while you are transporting explosive materials, you must warn other drivers. Put out warning signals like reflective triangles or electric lights if you are carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives. Do the same if you are driving a tank used to transport Class 3 flammable liquids or Division 2.1 flammable gases, even if the tank is empty. If transporting flammable materials, do not use warning signals that could cause your cargo to catch fire.

questions.question: A Class 7 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: Radioactive materials are categorized as Class 7 hazardous materials.

questions.question: What should a carrier do if hazardous materials are not properly prepared?
questions.answerC: Accept the shipment, but make a notation on the paperwork
questions.explanation: It is the responsibility of a carrier to refuse improper shipments of hazardous materials.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for the brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.explanation: The air storage tanks in an air brake system store compressed air to be used for braking. They hold enough air for the brakes to still be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: If your brakes fail when traveling downhill, decide what to do as quickly as possible because:
questions.answerA: The longer you wait, the faster your vehicle will go.
questions.answerB: The longer you wait, the more vehicles will get out of your way.
questions.answerC: The longer you wait, the slower your vehicle will go.
questions.explanation: However you choose to deal with a brake failure on a downhill slope, it is important that you make your decision as quickly as possible. The longer you wait to act, the faster your vehicle will be moving, and the harder it will become to stop.

questions.question: To help prevent rollovers, you should:
questions.answerC: Keep the load near the back of the trailer.
questions.answerD: Keep the load on one side of the trailer.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: To best reduce the distractions of a cell phone, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay on a single call for an entire trip.
questions.answerB: Turn the phone off before driving.
questions.answerC: Only us the phone to accept incoming calls.
questions.answerD: Use the phone to text rather than talk.
questions.explanation: If possible, you should avoid all cell phone distractions by turning it off before starting a trip and leaving it off until you reach your destination.

questions.question: What can rust around the wheel nuts indicate?
questions.answerC: That the nuts need to be replaced.
questions.answerD: That the nuts are the wrong size.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that they are loose. If you observe rust, check the tightness of the nuts.

questions.question: If feeling sleepy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to arrive to your destination sooner.
questions.answerC: Leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel sleepy while driving, the only safe response is to stop driving and get some sleep. Attempting to fight off exhaustion is dangerous and a major cause of fatal crashes. Stimulants are not a safe solution because they may help keep you awake but will not make you more alert. Once stimulants wear off, you will be even more tired than you were originally.

questions.question: To prevent trailers from rolling over, a driver should do all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a rollover when pulling trailers, you should drive slowly when turning, drive slowly on curves, and generally steer gently and smoothly. When loading the trailers, you should keep the cargo as low to the ground as possible.

questions.question: A driver should test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person that motorists should be worried about?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A child on the side of the road
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.answerD: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are not paying attention to the road. Be wary of road workers, drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers, and children near the road.

questions.question: How are dolly brakes released?
questions.answerA: By opening the air tank petcock
questions.explanation: Release dolly brakes by opening the air tank petcock. If the dolly has spring brakes, use the dolly parking brake control.

questions.question: When checking its automatic transmission fluid, the vehicle:
questions.answerA: Should be placed on an incline.
questions.answerB: Should be placed on a decline.
questions.answerD: Should be lifted with a jack.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's engine may need to be running in order for you to check the level of its automatic transmission fluid.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: To prevent fatigue while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: A hot, poorly-ventilated area can make a person sleepy. Opening a window, opening a vent, or using the air conditioning can help keep the cab cool and reduce the risk of fatigue.

questions.question: What is often found in compressed air?
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Tanks must be drained regularly to remove this build-up.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: ____ is an example of required emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: Before coupling, you can secure a second trailer by:
questions.explanation: If you are attaching a second trailer to a combination but you have doubts about the trailer's brakes, you should use wheel chocks to secure the trailer in place while coupling.

questions.question: When parked on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear flashing lights.
questions.answerB: Use one set of turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always turn on your four-way emergency flashers if you must park on the side of the road. This is especially important when traveling at night.

questions.question: Accelerating roughly is:
questions.answerC: Discouraged, as it may cause damage to the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Discouraged, as it may confuse other drivers.
questions.explanation: When accelerating, speed up smoothly and gradually so your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When an engine is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should come on and then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is ____ in a minute.
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: What is sleep debt?
questions.answerA: When you fall behind on sleep
questions.answerB: When you want to take a nap
questions.answerD: The amount of time it takes to get ready to drive after sleeping
questions.explanation: You can build up a "debt" of sleep if you do not sleep for adequate amounts of time. You can only catch up on the time that you "owe" by getting more sleep.

questions.question: What is reaction distance?
questions.answerA: The distance traveled between seeing a hazard and physically hitting the brakes
questions.answerB: The distance traveled between a hazard becoming visible and a driver seeing the hazard
questions.answerC: The distance traveled before a driver realizes they must brake
questions.answerD: The distance traveled between physically hitting the brake and coming to a complete stop
questions.explanation: Reaction distance is the distance traveled between the moment you mentally recognize a hazard and when you physically hit the brakes.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: During a pre-trip inspection, what is the best method for checking your lights?
questions.answerA: Parking near a mirror to look for a reflection
questions.answerB: Activating the lights, then exiting the vehicle to check
questions.answerC: Looking on the instrument panel to see if any warning lights are illuminated
questions.answerD: Driving in traffic and waiting for other drivers to let you know your lights are out
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should activate your lights, then get out of the vehicle to look at them.

questions.question: When driving through fog, a driver should:
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, you should use your low beam headlights.

questions.question: Areas of the road that are shaded:
questions.answerB: Usually do not contain moisture, so they can’t freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice on other areas of the road has melted.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight, shaded patches of road will stay cooler longer than other areas of the road. Due to the lack of direct sunlight, shady areas can remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead, you should:
questions.answerB: Stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and tell them of the driver's behavior.
questions.answerC: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If you see a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: The more alcohol in the body:
questions.answerA: The quicker the liver will digest the alcohol.
questions.answerB: The less effect the alcohol will have on the individual.
questions.answerC: The longer it will take to remove the alcohol from the body.
questions.explanation: The body removes alcohol at a fixed rate. The more alcohol consumed, the longer it will take for the body to remove the alcohol from its system.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: Shift into a lower gear, then use brakes to supplement the braking effect of the engine.
questions.answerC: The vehicle should be continually downshifted in the place of using the brakes.
questions.answerD: The vehicle should be driven on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: On a downgrade, the braking effect of the engine should be your primary method of controlling speed. Shift down to a lower gear before starting down the hill and save the brakes for additional slowing or stopping that may be required by road or traffic conditions.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, a CDL applicant may be asked to:
questions.explanation: While testing for a CDL, an applicant will be required to go through a full vehicle inspection. The vehicle inspection test will include an engine oil level check.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: It is best to hide your intentions from others.
questions.answerB: You should only use turn signals if there are vehicles near you.
questions.answerC: You should not use turn signals in construction zones.
questions.answerD: You should always use turn signals to warn others about your intentions.
questions.explanation: It is important to communicate your intentions to others on the road. Make sure to signal before turning or changing lanes, even if no other vehicles are nearby.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerA: Are not a cause for concern.
questions.explanation: The suspension system holds up a vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in this system are extremely dangerous.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: Containers of nitric acid should be:
questions.answerA: Stacked no more than two containers high.
questions.answerC: Loaded on top of other products.
questions.explanation: Nitric acid should not be stacked above any other product. Containers of nitric acid may be stacked, but no higher than two containers high.

questions.question: Drivers trapped behind a slow-moving vehicle often:
questions.answerB: Allow the vehicle plenty of space.
questions.answerC: Are happy with the speed of travel.
questions.explanation: It is common for drivers to tailgate slow-moving vehicles that cannot keep up with the speed of surrounding traffic. If you are being tailgated, allow the other driver to pass your vehicle.

questions.question: The steering wheel should be:
questions.answerB: Held by one hand to allow for other tasks, such as eating and drinking.
questions.answerC: Held by one hand at a time, alternating between hands.
questions.answerD: Cracked to allow for an improved grip.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper control of your vehicle, the steering wheel should be held firmly with both hands. Your hands should be positioned on opposite sides of the wheel.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: When loading a tank that is divided into smaller tanks by bulkheads, the load should be:
questions.explanation: Some liquid tanks are divided into several smaller tanks by bulkheads. When loading and unloading the smaller tanks, pay attention to weight distribution. Do not put too much weight on the front or rear of the vehicle.

questions.question: What is a bobtail tractor?
questions.answerC: A tractor that travels faster than the speed limit
questions.explanation: Tractors without semi-trailers are referred to as "bobtail tractors." Bobtail tractors are difficult to operate and drivers must exercise caution.

questions.question: If a tire fails while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerC: Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop.

questions.question: For safety purposes, when should you turn off a retarder?
questions.answerB: When you are carrying a passenger
questions.answerC: When you are carrying a heavy load
questions.explanation: Retarders are mechanisms in some vehicles that help slow a vehicle and reduce the need for braking. However, using a retarder may cause wheels to skid when they have poor traction. Turn off retarders when traveling under wet, snowy, or icy conditions.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driver’s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driver’s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears:
questions.answerB: You may have trouble putting the vehicle into the next gear.
questions.explanation: If you remain in neutral for too long while switching gears, you may have difficulty putting the vehicle into the next gear. If this happens, do not try to force the gear shift. Instead, return to neutral, release the clutch, increase the engine speed to match the road speed, and try again.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer attached to the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.answerD: The vehicle is on a slight decline.
questions.explanation: If a trailer is attached to a tractor, the adjustment of the vehicle's mirrors can only be checked accurately if the trailer is straight.

questions.question: Shut-off valves:
questions.answerA: Prevent air from escaping air brake systems.
questions.answerB: Prevent air from entering air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Override vehicles that are out of control.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: Which of the following determines your blood alcohol concentration (BAC)?
questions.explanation: The main factors that determine a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC) are how much alcohol has been consumed, how quickly it was consumed, and the person's body weight.

questions.question: If your truck or trailer catches fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Park in a congested area near trees.
questions.explanation: If there is a fire in your vehicle, the first thing you need to do is leave the road and stop. Park in an open area away from anything that could catch fire, such as plants or other vehicles. Do not pull into a service station.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: When looking under your vehicle's hood during a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the parking brakes and/or chock blocks.
questions.answerB: Leave the vehicle in a low gear.
questions.explanation: Before inspecting under a vehicle's hood, make sure the parking brake is engaged and/or the wheels are properly chocked.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: As a resource to police and firefighters, the National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards.

questions.question: If unsure if a road is becoming icy, a driver can:
questions.answerB: Open the window and check the front of the mirror for ice.
questions.answerC: Try to look at the road closely.
questions.explanation: If you think the road surface may be becoming icy, you can check for ice on your vehicle by opening the window and feeling the front of the side mirror, mirror support, or antenna. If ice has formed on any of these items, the road is likely becoming icy as well.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: Baffled tanks:
questions.answerA: Are ineffective in preventing front-to-back liquid surge.
questions.answerB: Contain bulkheads with holes, allowing liquid to move among sections of the tank.
questions.explanation: Baffled tanks contain bulkheads with holes to help control the movement of liquid cargo. These bulkheads lower the risk of front-to-back surge, though side-to-side surge may still occur.

questions.question: If a driver begins to feel fatigued while driving, they should:
questions.answerD: Drive faster to finish the trip more quickly.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the only safe response is to safely leave the road and get some sleep. Using artificial stimulants can be dangerous because they may cause extreme fatigue when they begin to wear off.

questions.question: When a tank that is divided by bulkheads is being loaded with liquid cargo, most of the weight should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the top of the tank.
questions.answerB: In the middle of the tank.
questions.answerC: In the rear of the tank.
questions.explanation: When filling a tank that is divided by bulkheads, make sure that you do not place too much weight on the front or rear of the vehicle.

questions.question: If coolant has to be added to a system without a recovery tank, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the vehicle running while adding coolant.
questions.answerC: Not use gloves to touch the radiator cap.
questions.answerD: Wait for the engine to cool before adding coolant.
questions.explanation: Before adding coolant to a system without a recovery or overflow tank, you must turn the engine off and wait until it cools. Use gloves or a thick cloth to protect your hands. To release the pressure seal, turn the radiator cap slowly to the first stop.

questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: An explosive material is most likely categorized as a ____ hazard.
questions.explanation: Class 1 hazardous materials are typically items that present certain explosion or fire hazards.

questions.question: Trailers built before 1975 are:
questions.answerB: Not required to have spring brakes.
questions.explanation: Trailers built before 1975 are not required to have spring brakes. When parking a trailer without spring brakes, be sure to use wheel chocks to prevent the trailer from rolling.

questions.question: Portable tanks:
questions.answerA: Cannot be removed from a vehicle.
questions.answerB: Are not permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are permanently attached to a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Cargo tanks remain on a vehicle at all times, regardless of whether or not they are carrying cargo. Portable tanks are bulk packaging and are not permanently attached to a vehicle.

questions.question: You will often have to drive your vehicle under bridges and overpasses. If approaching such an opening, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the posted clearance height is accurate.
questions.answerB: Assume the posted clearance height is inaccurate.
questions.answerC: Measure the height of the opening before proceeding.
questions.explanation: Do not assume that posted height clearances are accurate. If the road was repaved after the sign was posted, or if there is packed snow on the ground, the actual height of the opening may be different than what is indicated. If you are not confident that your vehicle will be able to safely clear an upcoming bridge or overpass, you should slow down and find another path, if possible.

questions.question: When starting the vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, the coolant temperature should:
questions.explanation: After starting your vehicle during the pre-trip inspection, you should watch the gauges. The coolant temperature should gradually rise to a normal operating range.

questions.question: A person who is watching the loading or unloading of a tank must do all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Remain within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.answerD: Know the hazards of the materials involved.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: While driving:
questions.answerA: A driver does not need to inform others of their intentions.
questions.answerB: A driver should only use turn signals if a vehicle is next to them.
questions.answerC: A driver should not use a turn signal if their lane change will be obvious.
questions.answerD: A driver should always use turn signals to inform others of their intentions.
questions.explanation: It is essential that a driver always uses proper signals to make their intentions known to others on the road.

questions.question: When asked about the vehicle's oil during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Indicate where the dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Show that the oil level is within a safe operating range.
questions.answerC: Show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
questions.answerD: Show that the oil level is below the refill mark.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the oil dipstick is located; show that the oil level is within a safe operating range; and show that the oil level is above the refill mark.
